Derived from: Crusade Bleeding Risk Score, Draft archetype [Internet]. Apperta UK, Apperta UK Clinical Knowledge Manager [cited: 2022-04-05]. Available from: https://ckm.apperta.org/ckm/archetypes/1051.32.839
[1] X. Flores-Ríos et al., “Comparison of the performance of the CRUSADE, ACUITY-HORIZONS, and ACTION bleeding risk scores in STEMI undergoing primary PCI: insights from a cohort of 1391 patients,” Eur. Hear. J. Acute Cardiovasc. Care, vol. 2, no. 1, pp. 19–26, Mar. 2013. [2] A. Ariza-Solé et al., “CRUSADE bleeding risk score validation for ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention,” Thromb. Res., vol. 132, no. 6, pp. 652–658, Dec. 2013. [3] E. Abu-Assi et al., “Comparing the predictive validity of three contemporary bleeding risk scores in acute coronary syndrome,” Eur. Hear. J. Acute Cardiovasc. Care, vol. 1, no. 3, pp. 222–231, Sep. 2012. [4] E. Abu-Assi, J. M. Gracía-Acuña, I. Ferreira-González, C. Peña-Gil, P. Gayoso-Diz, and J. R. González-Juanatey, “Evaluating the Performance of the Can Rapid Risk Stratification of Unstable Angina Patients Suppress Adverse Outcomes With Early Implementation of the ACC/AHA Guidelines (CRUSADE) Bleeding Score in a Contemporary Spanish Cohort of Patients With Non–ST-Segment Elevation Acute Myocardial Infarction,” Circulation, vol. 121, no. 22, pp. 2419–2426, Jun. 2010. [5] S. Subherwal et al., “Baseline Risk of Major Bleeding in Non–ST-Segment–Elevation Myocardial Infarction,” Circulation, vol. 119, no. 14, pp. 1873–1882, Apr. 2009.

details.purpose: The CRUSADE bleeding score is used to quantify risk for in-hospital major bleeding across all postadmission treatments, which enhances baseline risk assessment for NSTEMI care.
details.keywords: ACS, Acute coronary syndrome, Bleeding, CBRS, CRUSADE bleeding risk score, NSTEMI, Non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction, PCI, percutaneous coronary intervention, prognosis, ST segment elevation myocardial infarction, STEMI, ischaemic heart disease, myocardial infarction, primary percutaneous coronary intervention, risk score
details.use: The CRUSADE bleeding score is a tool to help providers consider the baseline risk of bleeding for their patients. With this, selection of bleeding reduction strategies, and increased care in dosing of adjustable anticoagulants should be considered. Lower hematocrit and renal function are the most predictive items in the score.
details.misuse: Risk of bleeding is strongly correlated with risk of mortality. It is not the case that those with highest bleeding risk are the same patients without a benefit from anticoagulants. Rather, the opposite is often the case. Higher bleeding risk, greater benefit to be gained from treatment. Key is in the awareness of that risk, and exercising care in dosing and treatment selection.

items.items: Crusade Bleeding Risk Score is used to stratify risk for major bleeding in patients presenting with NSTEMI or STEMI prior to initiation of treatment.
A specific date and/or time which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Hematocrit is greater than or equal to 40%.
Score for Creatinine Clearance estimated using the Cockcroft-Gault equation.
Less than or equal to 15 mL/min.
Heart rate score based on measurements in beats/min.
Less than or equal to 70 bpm.
Did the patient show signs of Congestive Heart Failure at presentation?
No signs of congestive heart failure at presentation.
Signs of Congestive Heart Failure at presentation.
Does the patient have history of vascular disease?
Prior vascular disease defined as peripheral artery disease or prior stroke.
Patient has history of vascular disease.
Does the patient have a history of diabetes mellitus?
Patient has history of diabetes mellitus.
The version of the score used, normally recorded as the year.
Issues that may affect interpretation of the score.
Relative % calculated by risk score quintiles
The total summed score of all recorded individual risks.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
Score based on systolic blood pressure ranges measured in mm Hg.
Systolic blood pressure ordinal scores are duplicated between 101 and 120 mm Hg or greater than or equal to 201.
Systolic blood pressure is less than or equal to 90 mm Hg.
Between 101 and 120 mm Hg or greater than or equal to 201.
